title: Charlie Christ has changed his attitude several times about supporting federal health care law.
text: The Republicans have disturbed Charlie Christ's ruling campaign, claiming that he has changed his positions on a number of issues, but perhaps most of them have mentioned his position on the Affordable Care Act. A campaign announcement by the Florida Republican Party says that changing its opinion on the Obamacari program is "awesome," shows that he first wanted to repeal the law, but now he's for it. We decided to put Christ ' s position on health care law in our position on Flip-O-Meter to see if he had really changed his mind. He has been charged since his candidacy for Senate in 2010 -- one time the opponent Marco Rubio accused him of having "six different positions" in the Health Care Act. We've evaluated half right, because we're really three. In the 2010 race, Christ said he wanted to repeal the law, but he also said he wanted to amend the law, and now he supports the law of affordable care as a democracy. On March 28, 2010, the announcement mentions a discussion about Fox News with Rubio, where Christ says: "I think what we need to do is move forward and cancel this thing," referring to the Health Care Act. Then changed to March 9, 2014, an interview with Candy CNN, saying, "I think it was great," when asked about the law. We found that Christ called for the repeal of the Associated Press article on March 21, 2010, while the United States House of Representatives was voting on the bill. At the time, he was trying to win the Republican election against Rubio. By 20 July, when he had given up the presidential candidacy and was running as an independent candidate, Christ was withdrawing from that post. The Wall Street Journal wrote that "despite his pledge as a Republican to help undo the health-care reform of President Obama, Mr. Christ now says that he does not support such a move." Then, on July 29, Christ issued a press release that seemed to take two positions simultaneously.
